ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Both in person and virtual lab
We also had an in-person wet lab that was not required.
Virtual lab lectures and activities, with optional wet lab experience.
Zoom meetings for lectures and group assignments

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I feel like I really learned useful lab skills in Biochemistry. It also reinforced concepts from lecture.

I learned how to carry out the experimental procedures we have learned about in lower level biology courses, and I gained a deeper understanding of the ways to use different protocols by synthesizing lab procedure with the more complex ideas we learned in Biochemistry lecture.
Lots of lab skills and lab report skills.
A greater understanding of the reasoning behind biochemical methods.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Really fun, kind teachers and TFs, all-around a good time. Everyone there is very knowledgeable and the material makes sense.

Quizzes should be a little easier, pls.

The online lectures were a little too long.  I understand that there isn't really a way around that, but it would have helped to have a few more breaks.  4 hours of lab straight is fine when you are constantly moving and doing things, but 3-4 hours in front of a computer it quite tedious.  Multiple short breaks would have increased my attention span.  

I think the setup of the lab is great.  Having each lab session be part of a large research project shows how all of the different methods can be used together.  It also made the lab report at the end meaningful.  After having read many scientific articles for other classes, it was fulfilling to write a lab report that was in the style of published research in a journal.
It is a great course. It is a full survey of basic biochemical methods in the laboratory. I would have liked even more exploration of new innovative methodology.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
I think the wet lab was really nice. I liked getting to learn with my hands in addition to classroom work. Although, the Labsters labs were also very helpful.

I just think rolling back on the quizzes can be helpful. They are at the end of class, and by the time youre done with the lecture, youve forgotten everything because of Zoom fatigue.

I really liked the mix of homework assignments based on journal articles and Labster labs - it was an effective way to teach us lab protocol when not everyone could participate in the wet lab session.  I also think it would have been helpful to have multiple short breaks during the 3-4 hour Zoom lab lectures.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It is required, but I do. I think its an important class to take, and Aruna is lovely.
Yes.  If you are interested in biology, it would be a great class because you get hands-on experience doing the experiments that you learn a lot about in other biology classes.
Yes, take this course. The professors love their work and it shows!
